Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Evolutionary Genomics of Range Limits in an Endemic Salamander
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will provide empirical tests of the major explanations for limits on species' range using a salamander endemic to the eastern United States. Most species' geographic distributions are not explained by obvious barriers to dispersal or limits on environmental tolerances, making understanding range limits a central question in ecological and evolutionary biology. In addition, understanding the factors that limit ranges is an urgent priority for conservation as climate change, exotic species invasions, and habitat alterations influence the ranges of the majority of Earth's species. With a better understanding of the mechanisms limiting species? ranges, species at risk of extinction due to global climate change can be identified. In turn, management can focus on targeting locations for protected areas or choosing species for managed translocation. Overall, the proposed research should have broad basic, as well as practical, implications because interest in species' range limits is widespread throughout the ecological, evolutionary, and conservation community.

Although range limit hypotheses are well-grounded in theory, empirical tests have lagged behind. This integrative approach will provide an understanding of the mechanisms that limit species' geographic distributions and lead to a framework for predicting species? extinction risk. The streamside salamander (Ambystoma barbouri) has a restricted continuous range in Kentucky, Ohio, and Indiana. Within the species' range, edge populations generally have lower genetic diversity and effective population sizes than populations in the center of the distribution which may prevent geographic expansion at the range edges. This study will use a combination of population genomics, landscape genetics, and an experimental field study to determine (1), if asymmetric gene flow from core to edge constrains local adaptation and range expansion, and (2) if increased habitat resistance at the species edge prevents range expansion. It is expected that these multiple hypotheses may all contribute to range limits, at least to some extent.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most species' geographic distributions are not explained by obvious dispersal barriers or physiological tolerance limits, making understanding species’ range limits a central question in ecological and evolutionary biology. In addition to their basic evolutionary ecology importance, understanding the factors that limit species’ ranges has become an urgent priority for conservation as climate change, exotic species invasions, and habitat alterations influence the ranges of the majority of Earth’s species. Although range limit hypotheses are well-grounded in theory, empirical tests have lagged behind. As such, we have tested major range limit hypotheses using multidisciplinary approaches in the streamside salamander to better understand the existence of range limits.

The streamside salamander has a restricted continuous range in Kentucky, Ohio, and Indiana which is not defined by any obvious habitat barriers such as oceans or mountains. We first tested for less obvious habitat variables that restrict range expansion at the edges of the geographic distribution, finding multiple environmental barriers to gene flow. For instance, a reduction in limestone geology across the entire distribution of the streamside salamander was associated with reduced gene flow. However, other environmental characteristics were associated with reduced gene flow regionally such as warm temperatures in the southern part of the range and high rainfall in the northern part of the range. This work shows that cryptic environmental gradients can vary across a distribution and have the potential to prevent outward range expansion at range edges.

We additionally tested if asymmetric gene flow from core to edge constrains local adaptation and range expansion. If gene flow is asymmetric between populations that experience conflicting selective pressures, then the receiving population can become sub-optimally adapted to its local conditions. With this, we performed a novel range-wide reciprocal transplant experiment to show that adaptation at edge populations is being swamped by migration from core populations. We combined this experiment with genome scans to find evidence of genes that are under selection in different potions of the range. Together, our results suggest that an increase in gene flow can constrain local adaptation and prevent edge populations from adapting beyond edge conditions, thus helping define the range limit.

Our novel, integrative approach has led to an understanding of the abiotic mechanisms that limit species' geographic distributions and provides a framework for predicting species’ extinction risk. With a better understanding of the mechanisms limiting species’ ranges, species at risk of extinction due to global change exerting pressure to cause unrealistic geographic range shifts can be identified. In turn, management can focus on targeting locations for protected areas or choosing species for managed translocation. Overall, our performed research has broad basic, as well as practical, implications because interest in species’ range limits is widespread throughout the ecological, evolutionary, and conservation community.
